title: CBP Data Analysis
text: vignette analyzes U.S. Customs Border Protection (CBP) data explore trends border encounters fiscal year demographic characteristics. focus identifying patterns encounter counts time across regions.

title: CBP Data Analysis
text: understand US Customs Border Protection (CBP) encounter data, utilized two core datasets, cbp_resp cbp_state. cbp_resp dataset details encounters different demographics fiscal year, cbp_state dataset aggregates total number encounters state. two data sets provide wealth information analysis, helping reveal key temporal trends geographic distribution patterns. First, loaded data conducted exploratory analysis contents, checking data completeness accuracy. Next, completed following work data preprocessing stage: Grouping cbp_resp data fiscal year demographic characteristics, calculating total number encounters group; cbp_state data grouped state calculate total number encounters state. addition, ensure reliability statistical results removing missing values (na.rm = TRUE) calculation. make data intuitive, designed two visualizations: first bar chart shows encounter trends fiscal year demographic characteristics; second horizontal bar chart compares total number encounters state. charts clearly show distribution patterns time space provide strong support analysis. # Results # Overall Trends Fiscal Year General Trends: Annual changes border encounters Analysis cbp_resp data reveals significant changes total number border encounters fiscal years, well trends distribution encounters across different demographic characteristics. Specifically, overall number encounters increased significantly fiscal years, phenomenon related policy changes global migration trends. example, years, number encounters unaccompanied children (UC) risen rapidly, indicating particular vulnerability group particular policy contexts. time, number recorded encounters family unit members (FMUA) adults (single persons) relatively stable, making majority border encounters. can see trends intuitively looking bar chart. data showed number encounters unaccompanied children increased rapidly given year, trend family unit members flat. changes can influenced number factors, changes border enforcement policies seasonal changes migration flows. #Encounter Counts State State distribution: Ranking border encounters state analysis cbp_state data, found significant regional differences geographical distribution border encounters. Texas’ total number encounters much higher states, showing importance major border state. phenomenon may driven long border Mexico concentration migrant flows. addition, California Arizona also occupy high positions total number encounters, demonstrating central role southern border states immigration management. hand, non-border states also show higher record encounters. states may host significant immigration detention facilities receive large numbers migrants transferred border states. phenomenon reflects fact management migration problem border areas, also involves coordination implementation policies within countries broadly. horizontal bar chart clearly shows number encounters state. can see chart, Texas ranks first wide margin, southern border states close behind. data provide valuable insights geographical distribution migration flows provide basis studying migration management needs different states.  analysis, found border encounter data contains multiple layers information, revealing important temporal spatial trends. time dimension, total number border encounters increased significantly years, possibly due combination immigration policy changes global migration crisis. example, rapid increase number unaccompanied children suggests group may sensitive policy adjustments changes external environment. Family unit members adults make bulk total number encounters, reflecting broader migration dynamics. perspective spatial distribution, southern border states occupy dominant position border management. Texas experienced largest number people, also likely major conduit flow migrants. southern states, California Arizona, similarly feature heavily total. addition, high number encounters non-border states also shows impact immigration management extends far beyond border region involve coordination immigration policy throughout country. Based findings, future research explore specific effects immigration policy, example analyzing impact policy changes particular demographic characteristic, studying seasonal patterns border encounters. addition, use machine learning methods predict future migration trends also important direction. studies can inform policy formulation, also help optimize existing immigration management frameworks.
code: # Load data cbp_resp <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-11-26/cbp_resp.csv') #> Rows: 68815 Columns: 12 #> ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Delimiter: "," #> chr (10): month_grouping, month_abbv, component, land_border_region, area_of... #> dbl  (2): fiscal_year, encounter_count #>  #> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. #> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. cbp_state <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-11-26/cbp_state.csv') #> Rows: 54939 Columns: 9 #> ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Delimiter: "," #> chr (7): month_grouping, month_abbv, land_border_region, state, demographic,... #> dbl (2): fiscal_year, encounter_count #>  #> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. #> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. # Preview datasets head(cbp_resp) #> # A tibble: 6 × 12 #>   fiscal_year month_grouping month_abbv component             land_border_region #>         <dbl> <chr>          <chr>      <chr>                 <chr>              #> 1        2020 FYTD           APR        Office of Field Oper… Northern Land Bor… #> 2        2020 FYTD           APR        Office of Field Oper… Northern Land Bor… #> 3        2020 FYTD           APR        Office of Field Oper… Northern Land Bor… #> 4        2020 FYTD           APR        Office of Field Oper… Northern Land Bor… #> 5        2020 FYTD           APR        Office of Field Oper… Northern Land Bor… #> 6        2020 FYTD           APR        Office of Field Oper… Northern Land Bor… #> # ℹ 7 more variables: area_of_responsibility <chr>, aor_abbv <chr>, #> #   demographic <chr>, citizenship <chr>, title_of_authority <chr>, #> #   encounter_type <chr>, encounter_count <dbl> head(cbp_state) #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #>   fiscal_year month_grouping month_abbv land_border_region   state demographic   #>         <dbl> <chr>          <chr>      <chr>                <chr> <chr>         #> 1        2020 FYTD           APR        Northern Land Border ID    Single Adults #> 2        2020 FYTD           APR        Northern Land Border ME    Single Adults #> 3        2020 FYTD           APR        Northern Land Border ME    Single Adults #> 4        2020 FYTD           APR        Northern Land Border ME    Single Adults #> 5        2020 FYTD           APR        Northern Land Border ME    Single Adults #> 6        2020 FYTD           APR        Northern Land Border ME    Single Adults #> # ℹ 3 more variables: citizenship <chr>, title_of_authority <chr>, #> #   encounter_count <dbl>  # Summary of data summary(cbp_resp) #>   fiscal_year   month_grouping      month_abbv         component         #>  Min.   :2020   Length:68815       Length:68815       Length:68815       #>  1st Qu.:2021   Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   #>  Median :2022   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   #>  Mean   :2022                                                            #>  3rd Qu.:2023                                                            #>  Max.   :2024                                                            #>  land_border_region area_of_responsibility   aor_abbv         #>  Length:68815       Length:68815           Length:68815       #>  Class :character   Class :character       Class :character   #>  Mode  :character   Mode  :character       Mode  :character   #>                                                               #>                                                               #>                                                               #>  demographic        citizenship        title_of_authority encounter_type     #>  Length:68815       Length:68815       Length:68815       Length:68815       #>  Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   #>  Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   #>                                                                              #>                                                                              #>                                                                              #>  encounter_count   #>  Min.   :    0.0   #>  1st Qu.:    2.0   #>  Median :    9.0   #>  Mean   :  166.7   #>  3rd Qu.:   57.0   #>  Max.   :25457.0 # Summarize data by fiscal year and demographic summary_data <- cbp_resp %>%   group_by(fiscal_year, demographic) %>%   summarise(total_encounters = sum(encounter_count, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%   arrange(desc(total_encounters)) #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'fiscal_year'. You can override using the #> `.groups` argument.  # Plot data ggplot(summary_data, aes(x = fiscal_year, y = total_encounters, fill = demographic)) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity") +   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "Border Encounters by Fiscal Year and Demographic",     x = "Fiscal Year",     y = "Total Encounters",     fill = "Demographic"   ) # Plot total encounters by fiscal year and demographic ggplot(summary_data, aes(x = fiscal_year, y = total_encounters, fill = demographic)) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "Border Encounters by Fiscal Year and Demographic",     x = "Fiscal Year",     y = "Total Encounters",     fill = "Demographic"   ) # Summarize total encounters by state state_summary <- cbp_state %>%   group_by(state) %>%   summarise(total_encounters = sum(encounter_count, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%   arrange(desc(total_encounters)) # Plot total encounters by state ggplot(state_summary, aes(x = reorder(state, -total_encounters), y = total_encounters)) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "steelblue") +   coord_flip() +   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "Total Encounters by State",     x = "State",     y = "Total Encounters"   ) print(state_summary) #> # A tibble: 48 × 2 #>    state total_encounters #>    <chr>            <dbl> #>  1 TX             5194011 #>  2 AZ             2106917 #>  3 CA             1757449 #>  4 FL              595699 #>  5 NM              589868 #>  6 NY              354491 #>  7 WA              132612 #>  8 IL               67282 #>  9 LA               66048 #> 10 VT               64733 #> # ℹ 38 more rows

title: Authors and Citation
text: Chen Q (2025). cbp.analysis: package analyzing U.S. Customs Border Protection encounter data. R package version 0.0.0.9000.
code: @Manual{,   title = {cbp.analysis: A package for analyzing U.S. Customs and Border Protection encounter data},   author = {Qiuyuan Chen},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000}, }

what: A package for analyzing U.S. Customs and Border Protection encounter data
title: A package for analyzing U.S. Customs and Border Protection encounter data
text: goal cbp.analysis analyzes U.S. Customs Border Protection (CBP) data.analysis cbp_resp data, found significant differences distribution different demographic characteristics (family unit members (FMUA), unaccompanied children (UC)) border encounters.

title: A package for analyzing U.S. Customs and Border Protection encounter data
text: can install development version cbp.analysis like :

title: A package for analyzing U.S. Customs and Border Protection encounter data
text: basic example shows solve common problem: Example: Exploring Trends Border Encounters Demographic # Result 1.example solves common problem: analyze annual trends specific demographic categories. 2. data filtered summarized filter group_by, clearly showing changing trend target population. 3. generated graph shows total number encounters per fiscal year, users can infer trends potential causes based data.
code: library(cbp.analysis) # Load the package library(cbp.analysis)  # Load the dataset data("cbp_resp", package = "cbp.analysis")  # Filter data for "Unaccompanied Children" uc_data <- cbp_resp[cbp_resp$demographic == "Unaccompanied Children", ]  # Summarize total encounters by fiscal year library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union uc_summary <- uc_data %>%   group_by(fiscal_year) %>%   summarise(total_encounters = sum(encounter_count, na.rm = TRUE))  # Visualize the trend library(ggplot2) ggplot(uc_summary, aes(x = fiscal_year, y = total_encounters)) +   geom_line(color = "blue", size = 1) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "Trends in Encounters for Unaccompanied Children",     x = "Fiscal Year",     y = "Total Encounters"   ) #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead. #> This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. #> Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was #> generated. data("cbp_resp", package = "cbp.analysis") uc_data <- cbp_resp[cbp_resp$demographic == "Unaccompanied Children", ]  uc_summary <- uc_data %>%   group_by(fiscal_year) %>%   summarise(total_encounters = sum(encounter_count, na.rm = TRUE))  ggplot(uc_summary, aes(x = fiscal_year, y = total_encounters)) +   geom_line(color = "blue", size = 1) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "Trends in Encounters for Unaccompanied Children",     x = "Fiscal Year",     y = "Total Encounters"   )

title: CBP Response Data — cbp_resp
text: dataset contains information border encounters, categorized fiscal year, demographics, attributes.

title: CBP Response Data — cbp_resp
text: data frame columns: fiscal_year Fiscal year encounters. demographic Demographic group encounters (e.g., "Unaccompanied Children"). encounter_count Number encounters recorded.

title: CBP State Data — cbp_state
text: dataset provides state-level summaries CBP encounters.

title: CBP State Data — cbp_state
text: data frame columns: state State encounters occurred. encounter_count Total number encounters state.

text: 1 point: Enabled package 3 points: clear README.Rmd / README.md displays home page 1 point: pkgdown set Github pages, accesible URL README

text: 10 points Create vignette using provided Rmd file uses provided data objects, shows easy understand analysis data. Grammar spelling critical Vignette introduction, methods (code used) conclusion based analysis Vignette take approximately 5 minutes read , roughly 600-1000 words. strict limit taken guide
